statement.p:
Consider vectors \begin{aligned} \vvec_1=\twovec{1}{2}, \amp \vvec_2=\twovec{1}{-3} \\ \wvec_1=\twovec{2}{3}, \amp \wvec_2=\twovec{-1}{-2} \text{.} \\ \end{aligned}
and let \bcal = \{\vvec_1,\vvec_2\} and \ccal = \{\wvec_1,\wvec_2\}.
Explain why \bcal and \ccal are both bases of \real^2.
If \xvec = \twovec{5}{-3}, find \coords{\xvec}{\bcal} and \coords{\xvec}{\ccal}.
If \coords{\xvec}{\bcal}=\twovec{2}{-4}, find \xvec and \coords{\xvec}{\ccal}.
If \coords{\xvec}{\ccal}=\twovec{-3}{2}, find \xvec and \coords{\xvec}{\bcal}.
Find a matrix Q such that \coords{\xvec}{\bcal} = Q\coords{\xvec}{\ccal}.

li.p:
In both cases, we see that
P_{\bcal}=\left[\begin{array}{rr} \vvec_1\amp\vvec_2 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1\amp0\\ 0\amp1\\ \end{array}\right],~~~ P_{\ccal}=\left[\begin{array}{rr} \wvec_1\amp\wvec_2 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rr} 1\amp0\\ 0\amp1\\ \end{array}\right]
so that both sets of vectors are linearly independent and span \real^2.
We solve P_{\bcal}\coords{\xvec}{\bcal} = \xvec and P_{\ccal}\coords{\xvec}{\ccal} = \xvec to find \coords{\xvec}{\bcal}=\twovec{12/5}{13/5} and \coords{\xvec}{\ccal}=\twovec{13}{21}.
We have \xvec=P_{\bcal}\coords{\xvec}{\bcal} = \twovec{-2}{16}. We then solve P_{\ccal}\coords{\xvec}{\ccal} = \twovec{-2}{16} to find \coords{\xvec}{\ccal}=\twovec{-20}{-38}.
In the same way, we find \xvec=\twovec{-8}{-13} and \coords{\xvec}{\ccal}=\twovec{-37/5}{-3/5}.

We have \coords{\xvec}{\bcal} = P_{\bcal}^{-1}\xvec = P_{\bcal}^{-1}P_{\ccal}\coords{\xvec}{\ccal}, which shows that Q = P_{\bcal}^{-1}P_{\ccal}= \left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac95 \amp -1 \\ \frac15 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .
The sets of the vectors are both linearly independent and span \real^2.
\coords{\xvec}{\bcal}=\twovec{12/5}{13/5} and \coords{\xvec}{\ccal}=\twovec{13}{21}.
\xvec= \twovec{-2}{16} and \coords{\xvec}{\ccal}=\twovec{-20}{-38}.
\xvec=\twovec{-8}{-13} and \coords{\xvec}{\ccal}=\twovec{-37/5}{-3/5}.
Q = \left[\begin{array}{rr} \frac95 \amp -1 \\ \frac15 \amp 0 \\ \end{array}\right] .

statement.p:
Consider the following vectors in \real^3:
\vvec_1=\threevec{1}{3}{2}, \vvec_2=\threevec{0}{1}{4}, \vvec_3=\threevec{-2}{-5}{0}, \vvec_4=\threevec{-2}{-1}{-1}, \vvec_5=\threevec{1}{-2}{-1} .
Do these vectors form a basis for \real^3? Explain your thinking.
Find a subset of these vectors that forms a basis of \real^3.
Suppose you have a set of vectors \vvec_1, \vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_6 in \real^4 such that
\left[\begin{array}{rrrr} \vvec_1 \amp \vvec_2 \amp \ldots \amp \vvec_6 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{rrrrrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -2 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 3 \amp 0 \amp -4 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 1 \\ \end{array}\right] . Find a subset of the vectors that forms a basis for \real^4.

li.p: From the reduced row echelon form, we see that the set of vectors spans \real^3 because there is a pivot position in every row. We also see that \vvec_3 = -2\vvec_1+\vvec_2 and \vvec_5 = -\vvec_1-\vvec_4. This means that \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_4 will span \real^3 and therefore form a basis.
In the same way, we see that \vvec_1, \vvec_2, \vvec_4, and \vvec_6 for a basis for \real^4.
No, because a basis for \real^3 must contain exactly three vectors.
\vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_4.
\vvec_1, \vvec_2, \vvec_4, and \vvec_6.

statement.p:
Determine whether the following statements are true or false and provide a justification for your response.
If the columns of a matrix A form a basis for \real^m, then A is invertible.
There must be 125 vectors in a basis for \real^{125}.
If \bcal=\{\vvec_1,\vvec_2,\ldots,\vvec_n\} is a basis of \real^m, then every vector in \real^m can be expressed as a linear combination of basis vectors.
The coordinates \coords{\xvec}{\bcal} are the weights that form \xvec as a linear combination of basis vectors.
If the basis vectors form the columns of the matrix P_{\bcal}, then \coords{\xvec}{\bcal} = P_{\bcal}\xvec.

li.p: True. If the columns of A form a basis, then A has a pivot position in every row and every column. Therefore, the reduced row echelon form of A is the identity matrix, which implies that A is invertible.
True. The number of vectors in a basis of \real^m must be m.
True. If \bcal is a basis, then the vectors in \bcal span \real^m, which means that every vector in \real^m can be written as a linear combination of the vectors in \bcal.
True. This is the definition of \coords{\xvec}{\bcal}.
False. The relationship is \xvec=P_{\bcal}\coords{\xvec}{\bcal}.
True
True
True

statement.p:
Provide a justification for your response to each of the following questions.
Suppose you have m linearly independent vectors in \real^m. Can you guarantee that they form a basis of \real^m?
If A is an invertible m\times m matrix, do the columns necessarily form a basis of \real^m?
Suppose we have an invertible m\times m matrix A, and we perform a sequence of row operations on A to form a matrix B. Can you guarantee that the columns of B form a basis for \real^m?
Suppose you have a set of 10 vectors in \real^{10} and that every vector in \real^{10} can be written as a linear combination of these vectors. Can you guarantee that this set of vectors is a basis for \real^{10}?

li.p: Yes. A matrix formed from m linearly independent vectors in \real^m will have a pivot position in every column. Since the matrix has the same number of rows and columns, there must also be a pivot position in every row. This means that the vectors span \real^m and therefore form a basis.
Yes. An invertible matrix is row equivalent to the identity matrix, which means that the columns are linearly independent and span \real^m. This implies that the columns form a basis of \real^m.
Yes. The matrix A is row equivalent to the identity matrix so B must be as well. This means that the columns of B form a basis for \real^m.

Yes. The span of the set of vectors is \real^{10}, which says that the associated matrix is square and has a pivot position in every row. Therefore, it must have a pivot position in every column, which means that the set of vectors forms a basis for \real^{10}.
Yes
